clusters.title: X files? Trump says he's ordering release of data on UFOs and aliens
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Orders Release Of UFO Data

items.title: X files? Trump says he's ordering release of data on UFOs and aliens
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said Thursday he is ordering federal agencies to begin "identifying and releasing" government files related to UFOs and aliens, a move sought for decades by some Americans.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said Thursday he is ordering federal agencies to begin "identifying and releasing" government files related to UFOs and aliens, a move sought for decades by some Americans.

items.title: Why did Trump order UFO file releases? #world
items.standfirst: White House orders government disclosure of UFO and alien records The president directed the Department of Defense and other federal agencies to identify and begin releasing government records tied to unidentified aerial phenomena and reports of extraterrestrial life. The move followed renewed…
items.content: White House orders government disclosure of UFO and alien records The president directed the Department of Defense and other federal agencies to identify and begin releasing government records tied to unidentified aerial phenomena and reports of extraterrestrial life. The move followed renewed…

items.title: Trump orders Pentagon, other US agencies to release files on UFOs and aliens
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Thursday night announced that he is ordering the Pentagon and other US departments and agencies to identify and release government files related to extraterrestrial life, unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP), and unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Hours earlier, Trump accused former US president Barack Obama of revealing classified information on the issue.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Thursday night announced that he is ordering the Pentagon and other US departments and agencies to identify and release government files related to extraterrestrial life, unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP), and unidentified flying objects (UFOs). Hours earlier, Trump accused former US president Barack Obama of revealing classified information on the issue.

items.content: What the White House directed on unidentified aerial phenomena records The president ordered federal agencies to begin identifying and releasing government records related to unidentified aerial phenomena—commonly referred to as UFOs or aliens. items.title: Trump directs US government to prepare release of files on aliens and UFOs

items.content: President Donald Trump said Thursday that he's directing the Pentagon and other government agencies to release files related to extraterrestrials and UFOs because of "tremendous interest."(Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)

items.title: Trump orders Pentagon, federal agencies to release files on UFOs and aliens

items.title: How will Trump's UFO files order play out? #world
items.standfirst: What the order to release government files is likely to involve The White House has directed the Department of Defense and other agencies to identify and prepare government records related to unidentified aerial phenomena and any matters tied to “alien and extraterrestrial life.” The move was…
items.content: What the order to release government files is likely to involve The White House has directed the Department of Defense and other agencies to identify and prepare government records related to unidentified aerial phenomena and any matters tied to “alien and extraterrestrial life.” The move was…

items.title: Trump says he will order the release of Pentagon files on aliens and UFOs
items.standfirst: The president’s announcement came after predecessor Barack Obama went viral last week for saying aliens are ‘real’Donald Trump has announced he is directing the defense department and other agencies to release whatever files they have on the search for alien life.In a post on his social media platform, Trump said that he will ask the defense secretary and others “to begin the process of identifying and releasing Government files related to alien and extraterrestrial life, unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP), and unidentified flying objects (UFOs).” Continue reading...
items.content: The president’s announcement came after predecessor Barack Obama went viral last week for saying aliens are ‘real’Donald Trump has announced he is directing the defense department and other agencies to release whatever files they have on the search for alien life.In a post on his social media platform, Trump said that he will ask the defense secretary and others “to begin the process of identifying and releasing Government files related to alien and extraterrestrial life, unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP), and unidentified flying objects (UFOs).” Continue reading...

items.title: Trump tells Pentagon to release files on UFOs and "alien and extraterrestrial life"
items.standfirst: President Trump directed his administration to release files on UFOs and any "alien and extraterrestrial life," an issue that has drawn decades of fascination — and spawned more than a few wild theories.
items.content: President Trump directed his administration to release files on UFOs and any "alien and extraterrestrial life," an issue that has drawn decades of fascination — and spawned more than a few wild theories.

items.title: 'Grey's Anatomy' star Eric Dane dies at 53 after ALS battle
items.standfirst: Eric Dane, an actor known for roles in "Grey’s Anatomy" and "Euphoria", died on Thursday at 53 from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, his representatives said. Dane, who disclosed his diagnosis less than a year ago, spent his final days with family and became an advocate for ALS awareness in recent months.
items.content: Eric Dane, an actor known for roles in "Grey’s Anatomy" and "Euphoria", died on Thursday at 53 from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, his representatives said. Dane, who disclosed his diagnosis less than a year ago, spent his final days with family and became an advocate for ALS awareness in recent months.

items.title: Eric Dane, Grey’s Anatomy and Euphoria star, dies aged 53
items.standfirst: Actor who played ‘McSteamy’ died on Thursday, 10 months after he revealed his diagnosis with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a type of motor neurone diseaseEric Dane, an actor in hit shows Euphoria and Grey’s Anatomy, has died aged 53, less than a year after he publicly revealed he had been diagnosed with motor neurone disease.Dane died on Thursday afternoon, his representatives announced in a statement. He first revealed in April that he had been diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a type of motor neurone disease. Continue reading...
items.content: Actor who played ‘McSteamy’ died on Thursday, 10 months after he revealed his diagnosis with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a type of motor neurone diseaseEric Dane, an actor in hit shows Euphoria and Grey’s Anatomy, has died aged 53, less than a year after he publicly revealed he had been diagnosed with motor neurone disease.Dane died on Thursday afternoon, his representatives announced in a statement. He first revealed in April that he had been diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a type of motor neurone disease. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Eric Dane dies after battling amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

Dane announced his ALS diagnosis in April 2025
He was 53 years old at the time of his death
Family and representatives confirm his passing

clusters.title: Ex-South Korean president sentenced to life in prison over martial law order

items.title: Ex-South Korean president sentenced to life in prison over martial law order
items.standfirst: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached president of South Korea, was found guilty of insurrection and sentenced to life in prison over his failed attempt to impose martial law on the U.S. ally. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports on Suk Yeol's short-lived power grab that sent the Asian democracy into political turmoil in 2024.
items.content: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached president of South Korea, was found guilty of insurrection and sentenced to life in prison over his failed attempt to impose martial law on the U.S. ally. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports on Suk Yeol's short-lived power grab that sent the Asian democracy into political turmoil in 2024.

items.title: South Korea's ex-president jailed for life over martial law attempt
items.standfirst: Yoon Suk Yeol's December 2024 martial law bid fundamentally damaged South Korea's democracy, a judge told the court.
items.content: Yoon Suk Yeol's December 2024 martial law bid fundamentally damaged South Korea's democracy, a judge told the court.

items.title: South Korea’s former president Yoon Suk Yeol jailed for life for leading insurrection
items.standfirst: Ex-leader sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour over failed martial law declaration in 2024A South Korean court has sentenced the former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life imprisonment with labour over his failed martial law declaration in December 2024, finding him guilty of leading an insurrection and making him the first elected head of state in the country’s democratic era to receive the maximum custodial sentence.The Seoul central district court found that Yoon’s declaration of martial law on 3 December 2024 constituted insurrection, carried out with the intent to disrupt the constitutional order. Continue reading...
items.content: Ex-leader sentenced to life imprisonment with hard labour over failed martial law declaration in 2024A South Korean court has sentenced the former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life imprisonment with labour over his failed martial law declaration in December 2024, finding him guilty of leading an insurrection and making him the first elected head of state in the country’s democratic era to receive the maximum custodial sentence.The Seoul central district court found that Yoon’s declaration of martial law on 3 December 2024 constituted insurrection, carried out with the intent to disrupt the constitutional order. Continue reading...

items.title: Former South Korean president handed life sentence
items.standfirst: A South Korean court has sentenced former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life in prison after he imposed martial law in the country in 2024.
items.content: A South Korean court has sentenced former president Yoon Suk Yeol to life in prison after he imposed martial law in the country in 2024.

items.title: Ex-South Korean president found guilty of insurrection over martial law order
items.standfirst: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached former president of South Korea, was found guilty of insurrection and sentenced to life in prison on Thursday over his failed attempt to impose martial law on the U.S. ally
items.content: Yoon Suk Yeol, the impeached former president of South Korea, was found guilty of insurrection and sentenced to life in prison on Thursday over his failed attempt to impose martial law on the U.S. ally

clusters.title: Austrian climber found guilty after girlfriend froze to death on mountain

items.title: Austrian climber found guilty after girlfriend froze to death on mountain
items.standfirst: The woman died of hypothermia during a climbing trip on the Grossglockner mountain in January 2025.
items.content: The woman died of hypothermia during a climbing trip on the Grossglockner mountain in January 2025.

items.title: Climber convicted of manslaughter after leaving girlfriend on Austria’s highest peak to seek help
items.standfirst: Thomas P given five-month suspended prison sentence and €9,400 fine over death of Kerstin G by gross negligenceEurope live – latest updatesAn amateur mountaineer has been found guilty of gross negligent manslaughter over the death of his girlfriend, whom he left behind on Austria’s highest peak after they got into difficulty on their climb.Thomas P, 37, was handed a five-month suspended sentence and fined €9,400 (£8,200) for causing the death of Kerstin G in January 2025 by gross negligence, an offence that carries a maximum prison term of three years. Continue reading...
items.content: Thomas P given five-month suspended prison sentence and €9,400 fine over death of Kerstin G by gross negligenceEurope live – latest updatesAn amateur mountaineer has been found guilty of gross negligent manslaughter over the death of his girlfriend, whom he left behind on Austria’s highest peak after they got into difficulty on their climb.Thomas P, 37, was handed a five-month suspended sentence and fined €9,400 (£8,200) for causing the death of Kerstin G in January 2025 by gross negligence, an offence that carries a maximum prison term of three years. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Venezuela's National Assembly unanimously approves amnesty law

items.title: Venezuela's National Assembly unanimously approves amnesty law
items.standfirst: Venezuela's National Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved a long-awaited amnesty law that could free hundreds of political prisoners jailed for being government detractors.
items.content: Venezuela's National Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved a long-awaited amnesty law that could free hundreds of political prisoners jailed for being government detractors.

items.title: Venezuela signs amnesty law as families await prison releases

items.content: Venezuela’s acting president Delcy Rodriguez signed an amnesty law that could free hundreds of political prisoners.

items.title: Venezuela grants amnesty that could release hundreds of political detainees
items.standfirst: More than 600 people may be in custody for political reasons, one Venezuelan rights group estimates.
items.content: More than 600 people may be in custody for political reasons, one Venezuelan rights group estimates.

items.title: Venezuela approves amnesty that could release hundreds detained for political reasons
items.standfirst: Venezuela's acting president has signed into law an amnesty bill that could lead to the release of politicians, activists, lawyers and many others. The approval marks a stark turn for the nation.
items.content: Venezuela's acting president has signed into law an amnesty bill that could lead to the release of politicians, activists, lawyers and many others. The approval marks a stark turn for the nation.(Image credit: Ariana Cubillos)

items.title: Venezuela approves amnesty law that could free hundreds of political prisoners
items.standfirst: Venezuela’s National Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved an amnesty law expected to free hundreds of political prisoners, marking a major shift after years of socialist rule. The measure now heads to interim president Delcy Rodríguez, who proposed it following the removal of former leader Nicolas Maduro during a US military raid on January 3.
items.content: Venezuela’s National Assembly on Thursday unanimously approved an amnesty law expected to free hundreds of political prisoners, marking a major shift after years of socialist rule. The measure now heads to interim president Delcy Rodríguez, who proposed it following the removal of former leader Nicolas Maduro during a US military raid on January 3.

ai_summary: Venezuela's National Assembly approves amnesty law
Law could free hundreds of political prisoners
Acting president Delcy Rodriguez signs law into effect
Measure marks a shift in the nation's socialist rule
Over 600 people may be released from custody

clusters.title: Three aid workers killed, 4 wounded in RSF drone attack in Sudan’s Kordofan
clusters.neutral_headline: UN Finds Hallmarks Of Genocide In Sudan

items.title: Three aid workers killed, 4 wounded in RSF drone attack in Sudan’s Kordofan
items.standfirst: The attack comes as the UN releases a report which found that RSF actions have hallmarks of genocide in el-Fasher.
items.content: The attack comes as the UN releases a report which found that RSF actions have hallmarks of genocide in el-Fasher.

items.title: RSF siege of El Fasher in Sudan has ‘hallmarks of genocide’, UN mission finds
items.standfirst: Report details harrowing 18-month occupation of North Darfur capital, showing destruction aimed at ethnic communitiesThe siege and capture of the Sudanese city of El Fasher by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces group last October bore “the hallmarks of genocide”, a UN-mandated fact-finding mission has said.In a report detailing the harrowing 18-month occupation of the capital of North Darfur, investigators concluded that the RSF and allied militias deliberately inflicted conditions calculated to bring about the physical destruction of the Zaghawa and Fur ethnic communities. Continue reading...
items.content: Report details harrowing 18-month occupation of North Darfur capital, showing destruction aimed at ethnic communitiesThe siege and capture of the Sudanese city of El Fasher by the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces group last October bore “the hallmarks of genocide”, a UN-mandated fact-finding mission has said.In a report detailing the harrowing 18-month occupation of the capital of North Darfur, investigators concluded that the RSF and allied militias deliberately inflicted conditions calculated to bring about the physical destruction of the Zaghawa and Fur ethnic communities. Continue reading...

items.title: Sudan atrocities are 'hallmarks of genocide', UN says
items.standfirst: A UN fact-finding mission issued the report after investigating the capture of el-Fasher by the Rapid Support Forces.
items.content: A UN fact-finding mission issued the report after investigating the capture of el-Fasher by the Rapid Support Forces.

ai_summary: UN report finds RSF actions have hallmarks of genocide
Report details destruction aimed at ethnic communities
Siege of El Fasher bore hallmarks of genocide
RSF and allied militias inflicted harsh conditions
UN mission calls for accountability for atrocities

clusters.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong Un triumphant at rare congress

items.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong Un triumphant at rare congress

items.content: Analysts say the reclusive regime is in its strongest geopolitical and economic position in years

items.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong Un pledges to lift living standards at rare congress
items.standfirst: Kim's opening speech focused on improving economic activity, with no mention of relations with the US or South Korea.
items.content: Kim's opening speech focused on improving economic activity, with no mention of relations with the US or South Korea.

items.title: Kim Jong Un opens North Korea’s 9th party congress, highlights economic gains
items.standfirst: North Korea has opened a major ruling party congress in Pyongyang, state media said on Friday, a rare gathering held roughly every five years that analysts say will set national priorities, including nuclear policy. The Workers’ Party congress is the regime’s top political event and often signals policy shifts or leadership changes.
items.content: North Korea has opened a major ruling party congress in Pyongyang, state media said on Friday, a rare gathering held roughly every five years that analysts say will set national priorities, including nuclear policy. The Workers’ Party congress is the regime’s top political event and often signals policy shifts or leadership changes.

ai_summary: North Korea's Kim Jong Un opens rare party congress

clusters.title: More than 1,000 Kenyans lured to fight for Russia in Ukraine war, report says
clusters.neutral_headline: Kenyans Recruited To Fight In Ukraine

items.title: More than 1,000 Kenyans lured to fight for Russia in Ukraine war, report says
items.standfirst: Intelligence findings read to parliament say ‘rogue’ agencies and individuals recruiting Kenyan nationals to frontlineMore than 1,000 Kenyans have been lured to fight for Russia in its war with Ukraine, according to an intelligence report to the Kenyan parliament that highlights the scale of a Russian operation taking African men to the frontline.The majority leader of Kenya’s national assembly, Kimani Ichung’wah, said “rogue recruitment agencies and individuals in Kenya” were continuing to send Kenyan nationals to fight in the conflict, as he read MPs the summary of an investigation by Kenya’s National Intelligence Service. Continue reading...
items.content: Intelligence findings read to parliament say ‘rogue’ agencies and individuals recruiting Kenyan nationals to frontlineMore than 1,000 Kenyans have been lured to fight for Russia in its war with Ukraine, according to an intelligence report to the Kenyan parliament that highlights the scale of a Russian operation taking African men to the frontline.The majority leader of Kenya’s national assembly, Kimani Ichung’wah, said “rogue recruitment agencies and individuals in Kenya” were continuing to send Kenyan nationals to fight in the conflict, as he read MPs the summary of an investigation by Kenya’s National Intelligence Service. Continue reading...

items.title: Over 1,000 Kenyans enlisted to fight in Russia-Ukraine war, report says
items.standfirst: Investigators call the recruitment a well-organised trafficking ring involving immigration staff and security agencies.
items.content: Investigators call the recruitment a well-organised trafficking ring involving immigration staff and security agencies.

ai_summary: Over 1,000 Kenyans recruited to fight for Russia in Ukraine
